author: James Dunseith
title: Barriers to Entry = Proposals
description: People find it intimidating to start participating in Project Catalyst.

assessments.note: The proposal is taking a unique approach to quality onboarding rather than quantity. It may well grow substantially over time. I see this as a valid pathway to onboard people whom are shy about plunging headfirst into Project Catalyst.
It would have been great to proof that the problem statement is accurate. If the takeaway that more participation is desirable for Cardano to grow, the answer is yes.

I agree with the statement "there will never be "one right way" to onboard people to Catalyst". There proposed personalized workshops in addition to the townhalls can help many proposers and other stakeholders. These workshops when hosted on youtube can become a record for future rounds.

The proposal works with the human nature of 'fear of getting judged', of thinking that our idea might not be as good as we think, and sometimes it freezes us, causing a bad impact in the Catalyst community. That said, creating a non-judging, free speech environment could add value to the community, and it clearly could 'encourage more meaningful participation', as the challenge asks.
However, I do think that if someone is too scared to participate in some way in the Catalyst project, I might assume as well that they will be scared to participate in these workshops too. In order to avoid this problem, maybe some workshop that people can enter as anonymously would help.

The problem and solution are clear and reasonable. The proposal is related to the challenge and can play an important role in value onboarding. The workshops can identify painpoints in the onboarding process of new Catalyst members, through the concept of first principles approach.

The workshops are focused on identifying the painpoints of the onboarding process and the results would be used to create proposals to solve these problems.

Although the idea is promising, there is no indication of a significant increase in participation / onboarding in the following 2 Funds (which is established in the metrics of the Challenge Brief), since the proposal is about the identification of problems.

This could be interesting. It assumes the proposer can find the new commers to bring in. Is town hall advertising enough? Is $10,000 for 12 catalyst skeptics submitting a proposal a good return on investment?

The idea is very good, we need to find ways to lower the entry barriers for new comers. The goal is to aim for Funds 7 and 8, as mentioned, and to bring 12 people in each one. This means that the cost per 'Catalyst Skeptic' would be $$416, which would be a bit high. I would like this to aim for bigger numbers so the impact would be higher. Since it would be a weekly meeting, $500 per week seems to be too much for preparation and running the workshop. I believe that the word 'skeptic' also is not a good fit here, because I'm not sure that skeptic people would be reached andwould like to participate. Also, some other onboarding initiatives are going on and I believe that some partnerships could be done.

I thought the idea was very important. In fact, the Catalyst project may seem like a very vast universe and one that requires a very high level of improvement of knowledge and techniques to participate. Thus, an action aimed at clarifying the doubts of possible new members and better detailing how things work in the community can solve a large part of these prejudices. This idea dialogs directly with the objectives of the challenge, because it will be a factor that will help the growth of the community and will also promote more integration among the members, it seems.

The proposer has the correct experience to ensure the proposal is implemented successfully. I like that they have previously engaged in earlier Funds and have insight into some of the barriers that newcomers to Project Catalyst are likely to encounter. I particularly like the line" some people will discover they have an exciting proposal to write".
The proposer appears to have a track record in the community.

Gimblelabs has been delivering training materials on Cardano-related technology. The highly successfully NFT project SpaceBudz had attributed its success to the availability of free API support by Gimblelabs. Therefore the proposal has enough credentials and experience to implement the project.

Although the proposer seems to be a long time active in the Catalyst community and the website provided guide to some good sources of information, the proposal itself does not provide KPI, does not explain how the budged should be spent and, which is a critical situation for me, it seems that it is not scalable – it seems that just one person wants to build the workshop and work together/mentor lots of people (if it scales up). Thus, accounting the feasibility I think that the whole process should be better explained (which platform would use, how it would actually work, how many people would mentor, credentials, etc).

The proposer is a member of Gimbalabs, one of the winning proposals at Fund2, which has been promoting improvements for the Cardano community. The proposer has relevant experiences for the proposal.

Although the proposal describes an excellent rationale to justify the idea, there is little information about the workshops and considering that there will be 8 weeks in each Fund, I think the more detailed definition of topics for the workshops is important.

There is a description of the budget breakdown, but as there are no details on the duration of the workshops, this makes it difficult to understand the feasibility of the budget.

There is a clear and objective timeline, but the Fundind rounds have been modified, and from Fund5 they will last for 8 weeks and not 6 as was foreseen in the proposal (this modification was recently decided, so there would be no way for the proposer to know) and this may require a modification to the plan.

I believe that the proposer had a very good experience and based on his participation in Gimbalabs, he's very well prepared to run such workshops. The plan is clear, and budget is well described, even though it seems to be a bit high for the proposal.

In my opinion, the team that will develop the project is still a little abstract in the text. Initially I did not understand if it is a single author, who already makes the idea happen (as you can see on the attached website, which talks more about the concept of the project and has links with some videos for youtube), or if there are several people. However, this is clarified when we look at this site, which has a tab that shows who is involved. The author of the text claims to be a veteran of the Catalyst project, but has not specified since when he participated, which would be beneficial to validate this information. He also says he is very involved in the issue of training people, which is evidenced by the fact that the project is already underway, which always brings a lot of credibility to the request for financing.

I felt the proposer has provided enough information to assess feasibility. They have included personal experience to highlight the hesitation that newcomers will feel towards PC and offer a pathway to onboarding these people. They may be inundated with applicants. I would like to have seen a little more on 'working with skeptics' as the crowd may require some careful handling for efficacy sake.
It is unclear how decentralization helps lowering the bar for entry. In my assessment it would complicate matters even more at this point in time.

The proposal is based on a theory that a personalized workshop for onboarding can help. There is a large number of unknown variables in the proposed methodology. However, it is an experiment worth trying.

Although it has a clear and understandable problem addressed, it has only a clear idea of what is the solution. There was not provided an actual project of development or explanation of how it all is going to work. Besides that, I do miss the tool to actually measure if the workshop is converting the `lurkers` into committed participants.

There is clarity the problem and solution description.

In the definition of success, reasonable KPIs and metrics were described.

There is a budget breakdown, but there are no details on the complexity and duration of the workshops, which makes it difficult to audit.

The timeline is clear and objective.

There are details about the proposer and a link to his project (Gimbalabs).
A reasonably simple proposal, thus easy to audit. I would like a more detailed plan on marketing to bring new people in.

The roadmap is clear, definition of success is also clear. Some metrics besides 12 'Catalyst Skeptics' should be included in order to better understand the impact of this project. Same challenges and risks should be assessed, like not having enough 'Skeptics' joining the workshops and keep attending to them.

The author determines a metric of success, according to the months, in which we can know the expectation of the results to be achieved according to the time. Also, it divides exactly how the financial amount would be divided, in parts. In addition, he sets out the answer to some possible questions from readers, something that I have not seen in anyone's proposal so far. In other words, the plan is very detailed, the information is cohesive and we can understand how the project would work in chronological order, making its applicability very palpable.

solution: Weekly workshops for "Catalyst Skeptics" in which newcomers identify barriers to entry that can be reframed as the seeds of new Proposals.
experience: Catalyst veteran and educator passionate about empowering people to solve problems and to engage with the Catalyst process.
